*Hi all, please help me with this query*: Is it legally mandatory to provide Earned Leave (EL) in India? Our company currently offers only Casual Leave (CL) and Medical Leave (ML). Also, since we do not provide EL, should we explicitly mention in employee agreements that leave encashment is not applicable, or is it sufficient to include this in our¬†leave¬†policy?

sender: Anjali Sathya TA Manager CADeploy Engineering
message:
Hi All, 

Small suggestion required from you:

One of the process owner has asked to revoke the offer at the late stage (a day before the candidates last working in his current company) asking to revoked the offer due to management meeting and change in the hiring. 

How to sensitively handle this? (This impacts the brands reputation and candidates situation) <This message was edited>

No EL is not mandatory , any form of leave is okay
Atleast from what I know Karnataka mandates to have sort of leave encashment or carry forward every year (although companies have liberty to structure it in their own way)
Hence companies use EL as only type of leave covered in encashment/carry forward

Currently, we have this structure:
Casual leave - can carry forward up to 6 days every year
Medical leave - can not carry forward
Then it‚Äôs sorted and compliant
Thanks a lot!

If you have to be labour law compliant, EL is mandatory. As per the Karnataka Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, every employee is entitled to annual leave with wages at the rate of one day for every twenty days of work performed by an adult employee and one day for every fifteen days of work performed by a young person.

Employees can carry forward up to 45 days of unused Earned Leave, providing flexibility for future use. At the end of employment, any unused Earned Leave is encashable, ensuring employees don‚Äôt lose the benefit of their accrued time off.
All this will be caught during labour law audits or if an employee complains to labour law dept. However the leave clauses needs to be mentioned in the  policies and agreements.
I knew thiz for sure as I had faced 3 labour audits from labour dept and during which we had consulted the labour law expert... <This message was edited>
EL is statutory requirement

Leave encashment are part of exit mostly, carry forward is YOY thing.  You can add this as part of HR round of discussion for new hire. Rest details can be part of your policy document.  You have to be legally compliant.

Okay, thanks for inputs everyone!

With this, I also recall one more thing. Some companies mention that they do not provide leave encashment as they do not have the policy or they provide unlimited leaves. Is it legal? I have seen this in 2 companies, one is a start up, and one is an MNC.
I can help! Quick call or voice note ?

If unlimited leaves given, labour office is usually fine with it. I have managed that with them for some good 3 years straight with 4-5 audits. 
Encashment is not stringent - you can get away with that too. 

What is critical is if yiu have a structured leave policy, then 18 days of earned leave + 12 days of sick leave for tenured employees is roughly expected in karnataka.
What is more critical is identifying what will keep your team motivated and balancing that with law. Being compliant alone is not helpful in terms of building a culture imo
Giving you a call!

Hello peeps, here's a trivial question (which came to my mind while I was talking to a just-passed out-from-college and highly arrogant founder) 

"Till how many hires the founder should be involved in the hiring process?"

Asking since the founder (mentioned above) says that they would like to be involved till the team becomes 500 (currently it's at 10). To this I honestly thought that it's too much for a founder to focus on hiring till 500 and not focusing on scaling the ops, customer base (I may be wrong in my thinking) 

Putting forward this question to the group. Thoughts?
I have seen early stage founders getting involved till 100. Up to 50 is usually high involvement.

sender: Muneera Ghosh TA Manager Captain Fresh
message: I feel the founder should be involved in the initial set of hirings and also for  leadership hiring, apart from that I feel founders should be more focussed in scaling the app and operations
Exactly, 500 is too over done! Arrogance at it's peak

After 50 they will stat becoming the bottleneck
It‚Äôs seems there is lack of maturity and fundamentals 
Running a tight ship= no final say other than founders is becoming a trend <This message was edited>
He'll get a reality check in a few months
Not more than 100, I think. Can be involved in senior leadership hiring or expansion hiring.

sender: Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared
message: Depends on how fast the intended expansion to 500 people is. If over 2-3 years and above, sure. If within 6 months-1 year, then no. It really depends on what the person is looking for in these set of people. 500 is not a lot if growth is measured and organic.

sender: Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared
message: Level of involvement is the real problem. because if they're micromanaging beyond the first 20 people, then it's already a bottleneck. so scale is not the real problem

sender: Anupama Murthy Founder AVS Technology & Talent Consulting
message: Generally they get involved till they are 50 or so and after that he will not have anytime to interview. He may not be arrogant but it‚Äôs all the initial enthusiasm that‚Äôs making him say that. You can tell him that it‚Äôs great that he wants to get involved and leave it at that. Anyway when they grown eventually he can take a call. How does it matter now? <This message was edited>

As a founder myself, I think it would probably be around 50. Its not scaleable otherwise. Maybe a max of upto 100. Then its your direct reportees who hv to manage and imbibe the same culture within the team
But its extremely important to warm up the core team and the 1st 6-9 months  from their induction is crucial

I think, its not about the number of people but the role you are hiring for. I worked with founders who loves to interview leadership or some sort of senior folks also after we acheived 450 employee strenght.
Leadership is still fine, there the involvement is still required. This even large enterprise will also follow. Not for every role.

sender: Ritika Sharma Sr. TA Partner Hackerrank
message:
Founders' involvement in hiring decisions may stem from a lack of trust in their leadership team rather than arrogance. but to scale effectively, founders should empower their leaders to make hiring decisions for their respective orgs. It's understandable for founders to want to be involved in certain critical roles, such as product or leadership positions but beyond that is not scalable.

A possible solution is for founders to review candidates' overall scorecards or get involved at the offer approval stage. This allows them to stay informed about the strengths each new hire brings to the team without being overly involved in every hiring decision. our founder operates in this manner and it is working fine.

Catching up on this thread a little late, but couldn‚Äôt resist jumping in!

Echoing what a few folks have already shared ‚Äî in the early days, the founder‚Äôs involvement in hiring is super valuable. It helps shape culture, attract early believers, and build momentum. But staying involved in every hire till 500? That feels like overkill and honestly a recipe for burnout.

A more scalable approach is:
- Founder drives hiring till ~30‚Äì50,
- Stays involved in leadership roles till ~100‚Äì150,
- Then shifts focus to building a strong hiring engine with the right people and systems.

Founders should aim to hire people they trust to carry the culture forward, not stay stuck in the loop themselves. Otherwise, they risk being the bottleneck rather than the multiplier.

Really loved reading everyone‚Äôs perspectives on this!

Thank you all for the perspective, basically i was correct in my thought process. 500 is a big number, sooner or later actual realisation will happen in the mind of the founder. That can show the founder to be a macro manager, which it actually sounded when I was talking to him. Max 50 is perfectly well, and then move the focus towards leadership hiring later on. 

Thank you all!

message: Hi I have reference sharing it with you

Hey folks, did some research and thought of sharing here for everyone‚Äôs benefit:

1. Looked at two types of organisations to benchmark our bands with - ones that have commission based roles (DoorDash, eBay) versus others that have subscription based AE roles (Salesforce, Zendesk). Selling in the first bucket is relatively easier because you only make money if the partner business does (in this case, restaurants listed on DoorDash).
2. ‚Å†The general split between base and OTE in commission based roles is 75:25 whereas in subscription selling is closer to 50:50.
3. ‚Å†For the subscription based AE roles, the quotas for AEs are generally about 5x of their compensation. For eg: an AE who draws 100K USD will roughly have a target to sell contracts worth 500K in a year.

sender: Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor
message:
I have added my thoughts and structured them with the help of Chatgpt.

*1. Founder-Led Search (Warm Intros)*
Often, senior hires come through the founder‚Äôs personal network or investor introductions.

This route is fast, trust-based, and ensures cultural alignment‚Äîespecially when there's no structured leadership team in place yet.
Investors or advisors can play a strong role in vetting these candidates.

*2. Define the Role and First-Year Outcomes*
*Create a clear JD and 30-60-90 day plan focused on business outcomes, not just responsibilities.
*Define Year 1 OKRs aligned with company goals‚Äîthis helps both in interviews and in setting expectations.
*Think in terms of "what problem are we hiring this person to solve?"

*3. Structured Founder + Panel Interviews*
Founders should do at least 2 rounds:

1st round: Vision alignment, business understanding.
2nd round: Execution mindset, team building, decision-making.
3rd round (optional): Deep dive into domain knowledge and prior experience.

*4. Bring in External Experts (VCs, Advisors, CXOs)*
If your company doesn‚Äôt yet have senior folks internally, bring in domain or function-specific leaders from:
Your VC‚Äôs portfolio companies
Trusted industry connections
Paid expert panels (if needed‚Äî‚Çπ5K‚Äì‚Çπ15K per session is reasonable for CXOs' time)
These experts provide functional depth checks, red flags, and help avoid "founder blind spots."

*5. Case Study or Assignment (Optional but Powerful)*
Share a real business problem and see how the candidate would approach it. This gives deep insight into:
Strategic thinking
Stakeholder management
Business judgement

*6. Discreet Reference Checks*
Do 3‚Äì4 backchannel reference checks, beyond the names the candidate provides.
Focus on execution style, team management, and why they left past roles.
If any red flags arise, discuss them transparently with the candidate.
That's helpful, thanks Shiv! <This message was edited>
Thanks Mitali!

Detailed one. Challenge that I have seen in the past while hiring these senior roles first time is that the Org will not have much clarity, many a times we want this person to figure out in depth and solve. Also 6 rounds is a lot , isn't it?

Competencies required for this role and how and who is measuring it the interview rounds is important while objectively looking at hire or no hire in the end. 

Bringing in the external expert as suggested is good. 

Any hiring will be easy if we know what are the "must skills" and what are the "good to have skills"
<Media omitted>

In early stages when we had to hire for such roles, it definitely started from the Founder chat first. In our case there were 1-2 more senior leaders so they would be involved too. 

Something we also actively did was to have other team members be the part of the process not necessarily for them to vote but to know about their experience of interacting with this senior person. We sought support of our investors in doing one round of conversation at the end.

message: Yes exactly. I am double clicking at all possible data points.

Just had a similar conversation with one of our portfolio founders on this. Requirement of 100+ folks in field sales and collections, but on company payroll.  Asked him to go with staffing model, ready talent availability, less overheads, onus of replacement lies with staffing firm. Easy to monitor performance, have a quarterly review, get high performers on company payroll and nurture. Candidates are also comfortable with staffing firms as they are assured of a job if the opportunity doesn't work out, this is not possible on a company payroll. Not every candidate can perform in different sales setup.
Yes, true take a data driven decision for such a large scale / impact hiring
So Iv done high volume on front line when i was with an Agritech

*My 2 cents:*
Go beyond the pedigree. If you‚Äôre open to hiring early career folks (1-2 yrs), look for people at startups similar to your stage or maybe one step ahead. These folks have experienced the ambiguous environment and understand how things work at an early stage. They would also have solved problems from scratch.
Collect a few basic technical questions from your team and ask candidates these questions at your level of the call. These could also be questions with binary responses. I also often asked my team to give me questions and also hints for how to know if the candidate is giving the answer in the right direction (b‚Äôcuz ofcourse these are technical questions, I would look for certain keywords they would use or approach they follow). This definitely reduced the rejections at the next stage.
Keep one round of technical interviews just for screening. Don‚Äôt invest a lot of time here but only max 45 mins where one of your engineers does this round. If the candidate doesn‚Äôt seem to be able to move the needle in the first 20-30 min, we would respectfully ask to close the call.

sender: Asmi Mittal Sr. Executive HR Ops Agrim
message:
Hi, can anyone confirm how the intern to fulltime conversion usually happens at your organization?

Do you also practice the intern exit and then rejoining them as full time?

sender: Gargi Rajan Associate Director HR Unicommerce
message: Yes they have to exit and next day oboarded as full time employee. There is no gap in between.

sender: Gargi Rajan Associate Director HR Unicommerce
message: You have to roll out a offer letter to them for full time employment

Yes, in our organization, if an intern completes their internship on 30th June, we treat that as their Last Working Day as an intern. If they are being converted to full-time, we carry out the onboarding formalities again from 1st July.

This approach is followed primarily in cases where the intern was initially hired only for the internship, and no pre-placement offer was extended at the beginning.

*For example*, when we hire interns specifically from campus, we issue a letter stating that they will work as interns for six months, after which their designation and package will be revised to a full-time role. In such cases, there is no exit or re-onboarding process involved - they continue seamlessly into the full-time position.

sender: Shiv Jha Associate Director TA Zolo
message:
Hi all, I‚Äôd appreciate your thoughts on this situation.

I have an employee in the night shift who has recently been taking frequent leaves citing medical issues. When she does report to work, she often signs off early and delegates her responsibilities to others, sometimes without my knowledge. This pattern has continued for the past two months.

While I‚Äôve been accommodating so far, it‚Äôs starting to affect team productivity and morale. What‚Äôs more concerning is that 2-3 other employees have started following the same pattern after observing her behavior.

I‚Äôm considering offering her a 10-day medical leave to focus on her health and return with clarity. Alternatively, would it be fair to ask her to resign with a two-month notice period - one month being mandatory and the second flexible if she finds another opportunity?

I understand that asking someone to leave due to health concerns is sensitive and ethically tricky, but the indirect work-shifting and growing ripple effect on the team are now hampering operations.

Would love your input on how best to address this.

Your idea of a 10-day paid medical leave is a great middle ground. It shows care and gives her space to recover, but also sets a timeline for clarity. Make it clear that she‚Äôs expected to return either fit to work or with further recommendations.

If she returns but the pattern continues, document all instances and have a formal performance discussion. Let her know that unless there‚Äôs improvement, you may need to explore alternate arrangements, including a structured transition or even separation (in line with policy

sender: Shiv Jha Associate Director TA Zolo
message: Thanks Lijo!

First you should have one on One with her, show empathy and understand things from her point of view.  Only thing that you should do right now is to keep things in writing.  See the outcome.  If she has personal issues with health then grant her 10 days leave as per policy coverage if you have one in place.  if she expresses difficulty in working in night shift check employment guidelines in offer letter mostly it will all be covered.  Then bring this matter to your management and keep HR informed.

sender: Shiv Jha Associate Director TA Zolo
message: So far I have had informal chats, she generally has health concerns on Friday. I grant her 2-3 days leaves instead of 1 day, I have been accommodating but I guess things are taken for granted. You are right I should get more formal and start documenting things
your meeting invite, agenda everything keep as evidence.  For any reason do not make decision without consulting your management/hr.
yes documentation will help or incase of seperation, so many questions can be asked by employee including severance, please document it <This message was edited>
Yeah, its tricky.  I had one such case but following documented approach as a manager is important.  else you will pay for it :)

sender: GV Sridharan Director TA & Ops Astuto
message:
Regarding their pricing. Few tips that I follow and have found success most of the time. 
1. Make sure your renewal is in the month of March every year, so they will negotiate more
2. I do not renew immediately. I let go for a month after the renewal date and then the CS team calls to negotiate. When they come back we have better chances on negotiating
Asking for a friend (a product company founder), does anyone know of a brand image consultant in Bengaluru?
Sonia Pardesi Image Consultant.vcf (file attached)
You can probably try reaching out to Sonia

We used to face the same music on every renewal , hiked prices by 100% without any rational explanation. It took us  2 years to go completely off Naukri. My team primarily uses Linkedin / Getlista / Clay /Lusha etc. It's a change of mindset and will take time.

While Naukri continues to offer one of the most comprehensive talent databases, many candidates still prefer updating their profiles both on LinkedIn and Naukri, ensuring maximum visibility across platforms.

this has always worked for me in last 3 years:):) please try this they have targets to close by month end so they will come back to you. just tell them we dint get approval  from management for this cost

sender: Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared
message:
Lot of them are actually very active on X. Identify a design leader there with good reach and ask them to share a post - they'll do so only if your product has good design philosophy/foundation behind it or product is compelling itself (and design is lacking). You'll get the ones hiding in pockets be interested in your role - you have to love bomb them here because if you don't take care of them here (whether a fit or not), the others will just never come to you again (good designers have a small community and word travels very fast)

traditional method is to explore portfolios around an idea via dribble, indiefolio, etc. these are usually curated by the platform, and then message them on LI.

old method is to post job for them in such platforms, which works but good designers don't have time to see roles on those sites - they see them on LI

sender: Sai Akhil People's Team Manager Ivy Homes
message:
Hey All,

We are looking to launch a internal referral program for our company. Majority of the role that are open on a recurring basis are non tech roles such as Sales and BD.

I'd appreciate any suggestions on what I need to have in a referral policy and what should the benifits we need to provide to someone who reffers a candidate and they get selectedm

Few I can think of 1) Payout timeline 2) Reference bonus applies to post joining only Not offer roll out/selection 3) You should have some math on what the referral amount is. Gen. fresher referrals do not work for payouts. Position Band, Salary range can be equated to arrive at what can be referral bonus. 3) Who is eligible to refer. (Exclude who are under investigation, exit pipeline) 5) You may want to think of unlimited referrals / cap on x no of referrals per employee.  6) For calculation only basic salary range will apply 7) Are referrals bonus payout taxable (get view from payroll team) in reality its yes 8) When will referral bonus payout gets credited; immediately post joining or in the salary cycle. But you should have solution sorted for a possible situation of, if joiner quits before bonus payout!  Trust this helps, let me know.
Hard fact only thing that works is bling ü§ë <This message was edited>

sender: Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared
message: Help needed on scenario here: there‚Äôs a CXO who has joined a team where multiple other leaders have already proven and established themselves. New CXO is hiring few folks (more junior to the aforementioned leaders) but his judgement is dissimilar from the group. These leaders took interviews of these folks but don‚Äôt find them good enough for the team at the proposed level. These leaders don‚Äôt want to ruin their relationship with the CXO either (CXO is not their manager). how do you advise your leader stakeholder in sharing this feedback candidly without offending yet making the right decision together (nothing can be written)

sender: Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared
message: Detail: The interviewed folks were referred by the CXO ^

sender: Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium
message:
- Are these junior folks for the same CXO's team or other? 
- What I've seen work in my case is candidly sharing examples of how people with certain traits similar to these referred folks, multiple times did not work well for the team's performance density and culture in the past.

If the leader is mature enough, they'll understand if this is shared with the right intent and demeanor.

I think there cannot be a blanket answer to this. The stakeholders and CXO should have a one-on-one for each candidate or all candidates together and the stakeholder/s should put across why they think these folk‚Äôs won‚Äôt be a good fit. The CXO might have solid reasoning for referring some of these candidates. Basically, a rational and candid conversation between two hightly experienced folks

sender: Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared
message: Thank you for these points. Main challenge is, while your intent is right - the CXO would feel not supported at the outset. CXO and similar level folks bulldoze through challenges to get results and it breaks real dynamics when your own teammates/leaders who you wanted to count on, don‚Äôt and CREATE blockers. Top is especially political as is and it frays relationships really badly, often beyond repair and actual trust. My stakeholders are struggling exactly with this.

People, need a bit of help. 

We want to relook at the leave policies in our org. 

We currently have 18 vacation days (PL), 12 days combined SL and CL. I‚Äôm curious to know what leave policies at your org look like. 

People with unlimited leave policies - I‚Äôm jealous already.

Companies with unlimited leave actually have employees taking lesser leave than those with limited leave. So actually you are blessed üòÄ
I agree, I have been on both sides to be honest, and I prefer the unlimited piece.
I think it is debatable we have 25 leaves paid leaves apart from other leaves and we are asked to use them.
Haha, same here. We implemented this at Kronos in 2016. But alas, employees actually took lesser leaves
Yeah, so you have paid leave which you are being asked to utilize. Unlimited leave, means there is no paid leave at all.
It's the same with learning budgets. You give everyone a value, but only 10% actually utilize the same
I'm not debating here.. I'm sharing a perspective
There is no actual right or wrong here. Each has advantages & disadvantages

sender: Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor
message: Quick question ‚Äî what‚Äôs the law around unlimited leave policies? Do companies with such policies allow encashment of leaves? If not isn't it non compliant ?

sender: Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium
message:
- Encashment is not mandatory. 
- Law doesn't speak for unlimited leaves. Its only a matter of audits that some day if there is an audit and the labour department observes that your folks have not been allowed to take off days atleast the minimum that's said by the law, then there will be a problem. Startups usually don't face such strong checks.

As far as the company is not restricting employees from taking the minimum applicable time off, all is ok. <This message was edited>

sender: Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor
message:
Not as per our compliance advisor, earned leaves have to be encashed.

Earned Leave (EL) / Privilege Leave (PL)
Employees in Karnataka are entitled to 15 days of Earned Leave per year, with an annual leave carry forward limit recently increased from 30 days to 45 days under the Shops & Commercial Establishments Act. This leave accrues at the rate of one day for every 20 days worked, allowing for a steady accumulation throughout the year. Employees can carry forward up to 45 days of unused Earned Leave, providing flexibility for future use. At the end of employment, any unused Earned Leave is encashable, ensuring employees don‚Äôt lose the benefit of their accrued time off.

sender: Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium
message: Not if you don't have earned leaves üòÖ

sender: Shivani Pande Sr. Manager People Success Rocketium
message:
This is more of relevance in cases where there is a formal leave policy, because then you also deduct pay when anyone has consumed the leaves. 
In an unlimited format, you're deducting the pay is not a part of any situation, so the company can get away with not giving earned leaves.

sender: Shivaraju K P TA Manager OppDoor
message:
Our advisor advised that we have to provide the earned/privileged leaves, as these are mandatoryüòÄ. We had to revise our leaves to 18 EL per year.

1.The junior levels are generally bulk hiring and can be done inhouse or through third party depending on the volume. Most of these positions are closed via hiring events.

Thank you, Anu!
Anyone else in B2B saas who might have some learnings to share?

Hi! We‚Äôve not hired AEs in India but I‚Äôll give you a breakdown of what we follow for RoW:

1. For the sales process, broad strokes of what‚Äôs evaluated in these rounds:
- Past performance: what kind of quota/KPIs did they carry? How familiar are they with their funnel conversions? Comfort with CRM and other dashboarding tools. Examples of difficult deals they‚Äôve worked on are discussed and our team has a bit of sales role play to identify how they do discovery, overcome objections, etc.
2. ‚Å†In terms of sourcing channels, LinkedIn has worked best (both inbound through job postings and outreach that we do). Response rates for outreach typically range between 30-45% depending on geography. We‚Äôve also tried out some country specific job boards too.
3. ‚Å†Generally 3 discussion rounds (recruiter < case study < reporting manager < leadership)

In terms of learnings, we‚Äôve seen that at least in the context of Headout, folks who have tackled problem statements outside of just pure sales tend to be better fits. <This message was edited>

sender: Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo
message:
Hey Guys needed your suggestions. Just wanted to know how many days to you guys give to a consultant to give a replacement, if their provided candidate leaves within 3 months.
Thanks in advance 
Sunit
Folks, any insights here?

It depends on the reason behind the candidate leaving the organisation. If it is due to org restrucutre and mishire, then it's on the firm to own up. If it is due to candidate changing their mind and joining another firm, then a replacement is mandated. If the invoice is not processed, then this can be held against the consultant till a replacement is found.
Typically, replacement should be provided by the consultant within a reasonable period of 30-60 days.

sender: Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo
message: Thanks Ajith
Self Community added Aruna Bhalla HR Head Reelay

@‚Å®Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo‚Å© - I'm guessing your vendor contract would already be signed & this would already be enforceable. Happy to share specific insights or guidance, if required
I‚Äôm actively hiring for these exact roles at a B2B SaaS startup myself.

Ideal Background:
	‚Ä¢	Tier 1 or Tier 2 college background or strong startup experience (B2B or B2C)
	‚Ä¢	Demonstrated career growth. e.g., promotions, awards, or performance recognition

Evaluation Criteria (Current & Past Experience)
	1.	Targets: What revenue or quota targets do they carry?
	2.	Ownership: Are these individual (IC) or team targets?
	3.	Attainment - What percentage of target achievement have they demonstrated?
	‚Ä¢	Cross-verify with deal size to ensure consistency (many AEs get filtered out here as the numbers often don‚Äôt align).
	4.	Can they design or tailor solutions to client needs? (Key criterion for us)
	5.	Do they independently close deals?
       6.  Double down on evaluating any short stints in their past experience

Candidate Sourcing Channels
	‚Ä¢	100% Outbound: LinkedIn & LinkedIn Recruiter Lite

Interview Process
	1.	TA Intro Call (15‚Äì20 mins) ‚Äì Initial screening and interest check
	2.	Round 1: Co-founder discussion
	3.	Round 2: Take-home assignment ‚Äì Candidate to research the product and prepare a product pitch
	‚Ä¢	This is where most AEs are filtered out, as it tests their product understanding, articulation, and solutioning capability.
	4.	Round 3 (Final): CEO interview

- Many valuable and unique learnings, too detailed to cover here

sender: Gargi Rajan Associate Director HR Unicommerce
message: Apart from the regular interviews - TA screening , founders, stakeholders,  i would suggest to get one round done by a  HR head (from Startups) from anyone in the network of the founders

You can also ask the candidate to create a roadmap for the next 6 months/1 year and present it to the Founder/s. Generally, the first HRBP ends up doing a lot of operations tasks as well so there should be alignment with the candidate on that front.

Wanted to check for Buisness intern - 
Which colleges are you targeting in Bangalore and Chennai? <This message was edited>

Hey, for hiring our first HRBP, I suggest a 3-step interview process.
Round 1:  C Suite round - CEO or functional leadership- discussion to assess business alignment, ownership mindset, and how they think about scaling people strategy in a fast-growing setup - strategic PMS, culture evangelism, roadmap to expand and support BUs.
Round 2: Functional or case-based round to test execution skills/ assessment followed by a C Suite interaction to discuss the assessment details‚Äîe.g., how they‚Äôd build HR systems, performance frameworks, and culture as we scale from 50‚Äì200 employees. KRA mapping, OD interventions.
Round 3: Culture and stakeholder-fit discussion to gauge communication, influence, and ability to partner with business teams, BU Heads, engaging strategic ESAT etc.
Optionally, we can involve an external HR advisor for one round to validate depth on compliance, PMS, and process design. This structure gives us a fair balance of strategy, execution, and culture evaluation

Thanks!

Kanini Sr. Manager HR requested to join.
I am using it.

- consider medical GMC (minimum ) and accidental (based on budget) to start with. 
- ‚Å†Employe, spouse and kids (minimum) 
- ‚Å†Parents insurance will require higher head count, if you at below 50 employees many insurers will not consider 
- ‚Å†between 5L - 10L Sum Insured is good to start with 

Also look at the demographics of your employees in what age group they are, if people are say 30-35 years above they would ideally expect parents, spouse, kids insurance and good sum insured. 

The more head count you have better per life premium you can negotiate.

We were not series A in my past company and now also not but this is what I had designed:

Company 1 : 5L GMC, parents included for those employees who wanted so optional, else its spouse+ kids. GPA : 15L.
Parents premium were on employees. 

Company B : 10L GMC, 5L GPA, self + spouse+ kids + Parents coverage <This message was edited>

Accidental (usually 3X of ctc)
Life (usually 1cr., but if someone‚Äôs ctc is above 50Lpa then 3X of it.

Coverage
